Key Match Events: Guinea took an early lead thanks to a blunder by Olivier Kemen, but were then reduced to 10 men in the first half after Francois Kamano was sent off for a nasty challenge.

Cameroon capitalised on their numerical advantage and pulled level in the second half, with Georges-Kevin N'Koudou's excellent cross finding Frank Magri at the back post and the attacker heading in with his team's first effort on target.
Karl Toko Ekambi had a shot saved in the 88th minute, but Cameroon could not find a way through to win the match.
Post-Match Reflections: Kamano's reckless challenge late in the first half saw him shown a straight red card and made life difficult for his team.
10-man Guinea struggled to get forward and were unable to register a single shot in the last 45 minutes.
Cameroon struggled to create clear chances, but were able to capitalise on their numerical advantage in the second half.
Cameroon are set for a big challenge next as they take on reigning champions Senegal, who won their first game earlier in the day, on January 19.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Cameroon's match against Guinea was their first in the Africa Cup of Nations.
Guinea's Francois Kamano was sent off in the first half, which proved costly for his team.
Cameroon's Georges-Kevin N'Koudou was a big threat throughout the game, thanks to his deliveries.
Cameroon's Frank Magri scored the equalising goal in the second half.
Guinea's Mohamed Bayo scored the opening goal for Guinea in the 10th minute.
Cameroon's Olivier Kemen was at fault for Guinea's opening goal, as he failed to clear the danger after a shot was saved.
